While it may look good, it contains the blandest gameplay of the series.
While it approches "strong" topics, it does nothing with them, and contains gaping plot loopholes.

This is not for the "smart" gamer. This is pretentious causualised bullshit.

I have yet to finish the first part of the DLC, but it really hasn't struck me as any different.

Even in the steam sale this isn't worth your money.

(Mostly spoiler free)

When all's said and done, a fairly disappointing game. The gameplay is certainly subpar, with lots of elements removed from previous titles. There is a nicely large variety of weapons, but this is completely undermined by the utterly unnecessary two weapons limit, which serves only to stifle player choice and undermine the upgrade system as well. Enemy variation isn't much to write home about. The regenerating shield is the first time that regenerating health has been tried in this series, and unfortunately really hurts the combat, since it makes cowering behind boxes and popping out to fire one of the most effective combat tactics. Also the only boss fights which occur in this game are terrible. Not just hard, but horribly designed: infinitely respawning enemies, limited weapons and a bullet sponge boss, with money deducted and enemy health restored every time you die.

The story starts off quite strongly, although as more of the plot is revealed, plot holes spring up all over the place and the conclusion is confusing, rife with its own plot holes and unsatisfying. The world is also poorly constructed, with the player murdering hundreds of innocent people for the crime of being law enforcement officers, then continuing to have normal conversations with Elizabeth, making Booker seem completely insane. Vigors are an adapation of plasmids from earlier games, but while plasmids were integral to the plot in Bioshock, vigors are very much an afterthought, with basically no bearing on how the city operates.

Elizabeth as a character is confusing. She has spent her whole life locked up in a tower, yet seems to be normally socially adjusted, which seems unusual. As a gameplay element, she is strangely shoehorned in. She cannot be injured or captured by enemies, who will completely ignore her, and can occasionally "find" ammo, health or salt (vigor power) around the battlefield, although these are not available through standard searching, only through Elizabeth. Her addition to gameplay is redundant, and only serves as an excuse for poor design in terms of ammo.

Visual design is fantastic, but there is little else to recommend about this short game, especially replay value. Don't buy it.
So so good. Love the concept and the game play is super smooth

This is the only BioShock I have played.  It is a very fun RPG/FPS.  The graphics are great and the story is good. The game takes place in the early 20th century in the flying city of Columbia.  Indebted to the wrong people, with his life on the line, veteran of the U.S. Cavalry and now hired gun, Booker DeWitt has only one opportunity to wipe his slate clean. Armed with only his wits and his trusty Luger, he must rescue Elizabeth, a mysterious girl imprisoned since childhood and locked up in the flying city of Columbia.

10/10

While it doesn't follow the 'traditional' bioshock plot, it carrys it out swiftly, and really comes together at the end. That ending, man. I even mustered up the willpower NOT to youtube the ending of the game, and I'm so glad I did.

Oh bioshock infinite, good game not great.  Probably the most over hyped game of all time, its nothing special but its fun, and the story is alright.  The gameplay is nothing new, pretty generic FPS.  Honestly I think dishonored was better than this game in every aspect.

The story of Bioshock Infinite deserves all of the praise it gets. It's presented in a way that doesn't overly confuse the player and when it hits, it hits hard. It tells a tale that mixes elements of both fantasy and science fiction that hasn't really been done in this fashion before. The art direction is stunning and you get a real feeling of place in the world, thanks to the smaller details and liveliness of your surrondings. The soundtrack swells during emotional moments, helping to drive home the fact that the story is not only a mentally stimulating one, but one that can still manage to pull at your heart strings from time to time. It boils into a loud, bombastic clash of strings and percussion instruments that is very reminiscent of Stanley Kubriks "The Shining". The major fault of this game is that if your looking for a game with strong gameplay, enough so that it can carry you through it on its own, you might be dissapointed. The gameplay lacks any kind of depth or complexity and while this is probably done to give the player's mind a rest after the more logically complex moments of the story present themselves, it is still only a mindless shooter with gimmicky, if fun, elements tossed into the mix. The skyhooks and elizabeth's tear powers do add complexity, but little do they help to make the player think in battle. The vigors are much less a carefully chosen set of skills the player has with them to deal with specific tasks, as much as they are general use and really used as either stuns, Area of Effect, or damage utilities. While this may sound bad, believe me when I say that Bioshock Infinite is truly a marvelous experience, worth the money and time, just not as good of a game. Certainly better gameplay than Call of Duty, but the quality of the game itself does not stack up to the quality set forth by the rest of the package. I'd reccomend this to anyone looking for a deep and involving story, but not to someone looking for a deep and involving game.
The ending for this game will always be in my memory as well as the reason that I actually researched across the internet to understand it, this is a must play.

An aesthetically-pleasing game that begs to be played twice, there's so much to pick up on.  I never finish second playthroughs, but I did for this one!  The other side of that coin, however, is that it's a bit short for a $60 game.  Gotten cheaper, that's less of a problem, and the replay value takes away some sting as well.

Excellent use of theme in the music, and it has good music in general.  And good voice acting, characters you really feel for, and a hell of a story.

Some people say the shooter action is lackluster, but I'm apparently not that picky; I have a ball with it.  The powers you get really add to the variety.  Play it, and make sure you have someone to discuss it with when you're done!
best game ever

How much you'll love Bioshock Infinite depends on what you expected out of it. If what you wanted was a collosal gameplay and narrative change the way Bioshock changed from its predecessor System Shock 2 than Infinites varied gameplay, frantic battles, and unique (if confusing) plot will do more than satisfy. But if what you wanted was a return to the more strategical and slower gunplay of Bioshock and its heart-wrenching ethical dilemas, than Bioshock 2 would be a better use of your money.

So... Bioshock Infinite. First, people loved it, then they kinda didn't and now everyone I ask is more or less indifferent about it.

Truth be told, I still really like Infinite. I see the game as a sort of antithesis to the Bioshock ethos, both ludic and narratively. The original Bioshock was a game about great Ideals, A game whose hyperviolent Aesthetics and binary moral-chioce system actually reflected the world you were interacting with. A game that made giant metal beasts with drillheads for arms and superpower-granting syringes seem like plausible things in the context of your surroundings.

Bioshock Infinite is all of that too. And it is also not.

This discrepancy is felt in every moment of the game and it can ruin your entire experience. Vigors (Columbia's spin on Plasmoids) feel entirely out of place. Almost no character in the entire game seems to act rationally. The level design is predictable and formulaic, albeit nicely done. Meanwhile, the Big-Daddy-replacing handymen are frightening at first but quickly become glorified meatsponges as the game progresses. The final battle is a tedious and frustrating endurance test that made me stop playing for almost a week. And yet, I still feel like these things are justified in a certain way.

I won't spoil the game, but I will give you my 2 cents on Infinite's Storyline: If you feel like the plot is going to collapse on it self, let it. That is all I'm saying.

One of the best games I have played in recent memory. Definitely the best FPS I've ever experienced. The graphics are mind-blowing, the setting is inventive and gorgeous, and it's rare to find an FPS that actually makes you care about the characters and the things that are happening to them. I also didn't see the ending coming. No spoilers, but the ending was a bit odd to me - and  yet somehow it worked. All in all, a fantastic game. I don't usually finish games but this one kept my attention from beginning to end.

The game had a nice intro, and cool concept. However, as you play, you will start to notice how shallow the game is. Environments dont respond to you, NPCs dont respond to you, and you feel like the game has no soul. The flying city did not feel like a flying city. You spend most of the time in rooms and hallways. You get a few chances to take to the clouds, but I really wished there was more emphasis on living in the sky and was hoping for more air fights. At many points in turns into a call of duty duck and cover til you win strategy type of game. The combat gets boring, the vigors get boring, the 'boss battle' is freaking rediculous - but with a great ending - I still felt somewhat satisfied and happy to have played it. If this game were a movie, Id suggest waiting to catch it on TV.

Bioshock Infinite has the biggest potential yet failed quite hard. Gameplay is nothing like from the previews while the actual gameplay really needed to be polished. The game storywise is a huge messed, keeps on jumping to theme and theme while making me care less for characters as the story goes on and there’s certain plot elements that does not make sense. Elizabeth is the most likable character yet there is some strange characterization to the context of her situation and the previews show that she supposed to be more helpful outside of giving ammo and potions. Environments graphics are good but character details, besides Elizabeth, is very poor and the game keeps struggling with my computer even when I but the game at its lowest graphics. If you’re still curious of this game despite my warnings then I highly recommend you to buy this game on a HUGE discount.

Tolles Spielgefühl von anfang an, stimmige Atmosphäre und zum größten Teil Herrausfordernde Kämpfe die sich nach einer weile leider wiederhohlen. Aktuelle Grafik mit teils Alterserscheinungen in sachen Texturen aber im grossen und ganzen auch auf älteren Systemen schön anzusehen, der Soundtrack und vor allem Die Synchronisation (Engl. und deutsch) sind sehr gut geworden und unterstreichen das Spielgefühl. Toller 3ter Teil des Franchise und wird hofffentlich nicht minder toll weitergeführt.

The biggest strength of this game is its visual design (Columbia might just be the most intricate and breathtaking video game environment I've ever seen) and the story. It's very easy to immerse yourself in the world and the story of BSI. It's unfortunate that the gameplay rarely strays from the good old concept of shooting people with guns (and some special powers), but the shooting itself is very solid and has a surprising amount of mobility for a modern shooter thanks to the sky hook things. I think my biggest complaint about it is that it's pretty linear, which is a shame considering how well Columbia would've lended itself to having big open levels. Still, if you like shooting things and you're a fan of great stories, this is something you should play.

Just by the pass; you'll essentially get one DLC for free.  Or, skip the pass and watch the Youtube playthroughs of the Rapture DLCs.  The price for the first Rapture DLC is an absolute rip-off; it's about 2 hours of content, if that (depending on the kind of player you are), and they're pretty much asking the price of a new game (or for BI on sale at 50% off).  There are a LOT of missable things; hell, I missed the special new weapon, which is probably why I had such a hard time with the final boss.

Elizabeth doesn't give you money, and she certainly can't find weapons or salts that are right in front of her face.  Be prepared to spend a lot of money at the Circus of Values; the game is very stingy with how many bullets you get, both for the weapon and drops.

While it was nice to see Rapture in its heyday, and then go back to see the splicers just before they became hideous mask-wearing abominations, it just doesn't feel worth it.  I don't know if it's the length, or what, but it should have only been about the same price as Clash in the Clouds.
Not the great game it could have been, but still one hell of a ride with a memorable story.

Bioshock Infinite possui uma história marcante e envolvente, complexa e profunda. Passada na controversa cidade ufanista de Columbia, situada nada mais nada menos que nos céus (isso, mesmo, a cidade flutua nos ares), a trama vai se desenrolar em torno de uma crença no Profeta (você) e no Anti-Cristo (você também) e uma moça chamda Elisabeth, em quem tudo se explica. 

Achou confuso? Jogue e você entenderá.

Lém de gráficos perfeitos, o jogo conta com jogabilidade muito bm construída e um nível de dificuldade bastante equilibrado, onde para se sair bem, você tem que fazer uso de armas de fogo e poderes (Vigores) que lhe permitem realizar façanhas incíveis!

Ken Levine, the game directory, knows how to make a jaw dropping start of a game. The first hours of this game are some of the most impressive gaming I've experienced. But the man cannot finish a story in a satisfying way. 

You should play this game a for a while and then stop and imagine to yourself how it might end. Doing this you will come away with an unparalleled gaming experience you can hold on to for the rest of your life. If you play this game to completion he will poison your initial experience and you'll be left more empty than if you had never played BioShock Infinite.
